nodes.text: Sponsors shall not represent investigational drugs as safe or effective in promotional contexts
Sponsors shall not commercially distribute investigational drugs
Sponsors shall not test market investigational drugs
Scientific information and findings about the drug may be exchanged and disseminated
Sponsors shall not unduly prolong investigations after sufficient data exists for marketing application
IRBs can be disqualified for non-compliance with regulations
Sponsors must meet applicable requirements for charging in clinical trials
Sponsors must justify the amount to be charged for investigational drugs
Sponsors must obtain prior written FDA authorization to charge for investigational drugs
FDA may withdraw charging authorization if it interferes with drug development
Drug must show potential clinical benefit advantage over available products
IRB must document findings when approving alterations to informed consent requirements
Clinical trial data must be essential for establishing drug effectiveness or safety for initial approval
Clinical trial data must support significant labeling changes for approved drugs
Sponsors must demonstrate that trials cannot be conducted without charging due to extraordinary drug costs
Charging for clinical trials may continue for the full trial duration unless FDA specifies shorter period
Sponsors must ensure charging for expanded access does not interfere with drug marketing approval
Submit investigational new drug applications per Part 312
Submit new drug applications according to Part 314 requirements
Show evidence of sufficient enrollment in ongoing clinical trials needed for marketing approval
Demonstrate adequate progress in drug development for marketing approval
Submit development milestones planned for the next year in the investigational plan
Charging authorization is limited to the specified number of patients approved for treatment use
Charging for expanded access is limited to 1 year unless FDA specifies shorter period
Direct costs for charging must include drug acquisition costs from manufacturing sources
Direct costs must include shipping and handling costs for the drug
Indirect costs include facilities and equipment costs primarily used for commercial production
Sponsors may recover costs for monitoring expanded access INDs
Sponsors may recover costs for IND reporting requirements compliance
Sponsors must provide documentation supporting cost recovery calculations
Cost calculations must be reviewed and approved by an independent certified public accountant
Waiver requests may be submitted in an IND or IND amendment
Emergency waiver requests may be made by telephone or rapid communication
Waiver requests must explain why compliance is unnecessary or impossible
FDA may grant waivers if noncompliance poses no significant risk to human subjects
Sponsor must submit IND to FDA before conducting clinical investigation with investigational new drug
Clinical investigations cannot begin until IND is in effect
Separate IND required for clinical investigations with informed consent exceptions
FDA must provide written determination within 30 days of receiving IND with informed consent exception
Clinical investigations with informed consent exceptions require prior written FDA authorization
IND may be submitted for one or more phases of investigation
Phase 1 studies should obtain sufficient pharmacokinetic and pharmacological data to design Phase 2 studies
Phase 1 studies should include 20-80 total subjects and patients
Phase 2 studies must evaluate drug effectiveness for specific indications in patients
Phase 2 studies must determine common short-term side effects and risks
Phase 2 studies should involve no more than several hundred subjects
Phase 2 studies must be well-controlled and closely monitored
Phase 3 studies must include several hundred to several thousand subjects
FDA must assure safety and rights of subjects in all investigation phases
FDA must assess scientific quality of Phase 2 and 3 clinical investigations
FDA must evaluate likelihood that Phase 2-3 studies will meet marketing approval standards
Preliminary evidence of drug effectiveness must be obtained before Phase 3 studies
IND submissions must contain sufficient information to accomplish FDA review objectives
IRB must review and approve informed consent forms when DOD determines consent is required
Initial IND submission should focus on general investigational plan and human study protocols
Protocol amendments should build logically on previous submissions
Annual IND reports should report status of ongoing studies
Annual IND reports should update the investigational plan for coming year
Sponsors should follow IND format specified in § 312.23
Sponsor-investigators may refer to manufacturer's IND if authorized by manufacturer
Submit FDA Form-1571 cover sheet with IND application
Include sponsor name, address, phone number, date and investigational drug name on cover sheet
Identify clinical investigation phases on IND cover sheet
Commit to not begin clinical investigations until IND is in effect
Commit to IRB review and approval of all studies in clinical investigation
Report proposed research activity changes to IRB per part 56 requirements
Name and title of person monitoring clinical investigation conduct must be specified
Name and title of person responsible for drug safety evaluation must be documented
Document CRO name, address and transferred obligations for any outsourced clinical studies
IND application must include sponsor's or authorized representative's signature
Non-US signers must have US agent countersign IND with name and address
Include introductory statement with drug name and all active ingredients
Provide summary of previous human experience with the drug
Report any safety/effectiveness-related drug withdrawals from other countries
Describe overall drug investigation plan for the following year
Specify the indication(s) to be studied in clinical trials
State estimated number of patients for planned studies
Investigator's brochure must include a description of the drug substance and formulation with structural formula
Investigator's brochure must summarize pharmacological and toxicological effects in animals and humans
Investigator's brochure must summarize pharmacokinetics and biological disposition in animals and humans
Investigator's brochure must include safety and effectiveness data from prior clinical studies
Investigator's brochure must describe anticipated risks, side effects and required monitoring procedures
A protocol must be submitted for each planned study
Phase 1 protocols should outline estimated number of patients to be involved
Phase 1 protocols should specify safety exclusion criteria
Phase 1 protocols must detail critical safety monitoring of vital signs and blood chemistry
Phase 1 protocol modifications not affecting safety must be reported in annual report only
Phase 2 and 3 protocols should describe all study aspects in detail
Phase 2 and 3 protocols should include contingency plans for potential deviations
Provide name and qualifications of each investigator and subinvestigator
Document name and address of research facilities to be used
Document name and address of each reviewing Institutional Review Board
Define patient selection and exclusion criteria
Describe methods to minimize bias among subjects, investigators and analysts
Submit sufficient information to identify drug substance and ensure quality, purity and strength
Initial Phase 1 submissions should focus on raw materials and new drug substance identification/control
Final specifications for drug substance and product must be submitted by end of investigation
Submit stability data demonstrating drug substance/product are within acceptable limits for study duration
Stability data scope may be limited for short-term clinical investigations
IRB must require documentation of informed consent per § 50.27
Submit information amendments for chemistry, manufacturing and control processes when expanding clinical trials
Provide description of drug substance including physical, chemical and biological characteristics
Include name and address of drug substance manufacturer
Document acceptable limits and analytical methods for drug substance identity, strength, quality and purity
Provide stability information for drug substance during toxicological and clinical studies
List all components used in manufacturing the investigational drug product
Informed consent must describe foreseeable risks and discomforts
Document quantitative composition of investigational drug product including expected variations
Provide name and address of drug product manufacturer
Include description of manufacturing and packaging procedures appropriate for the product
Document acceptable limits and analytical methods for drug identity, strength, quality and purity
Provide information to demonstrate product stability during planned clinical studies
Include description of composition, manufacture and control of placebos used in controlled trials
Submit information about individuals who evaluated safety study results and their qualifications
Provide location where investigations were conducted and records are available for inspection
Submit informational amendments with additional safety data as drug development proceeds
Include description of pharmacological effects and drug mechanism of action in animals
Document drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion information if known
Provide integrated summary of toxicological effects in animals and in vitro
Include results of acute, subacute and chronic toxicity tests based on drug nature and investigation phase
Provide full tabulated data for each toxicology study supporting clinical investigation safety
Include statement confirming GLP compliance for each nonclinical laboratory study
Provide explanation if nonclinical study does not comply with GLP regulations
Submit summary of all previous human experience with investigational drug
Include detailed information about previous investigations or marketing in US or other countries
Provide detailed information from controlled trials relevant to drug effectiveness
Physicians may provide emergency care as permitted by applicable laws
Provide full published material relevant to investigation safety and drug effectiveness assessment
Less directly relevant published material may be supplied via bibliography
For combination drugs, provide safety/effectiveness information for each active component
List countries where drug has been marketed outside US
List countries where drug was withdrawn for safety/effectiveness reasons
Submit information on drug dependence and abuse potential for psychotropic substances
Adequate provisions must exist to protect subject privacy and data confidentiality
Submit bioavailability/bioequivalence data for human drugs per Part 320
Sponsors may only recover direct costs specifically attributed to providing the authorized investigational drug
Submit product development protocol for medical devices under section 515
Sponsors may recover administrative costs directly associated with expanded access INDs
IND application must include a table of contents
All protocols must state study objectives and purpose
Document planned drug dosage, maximum dose and duration of patient exposure
Describe procedures and tests to monitor drug effects and minimize risk to subjects
IRB may waive written consent for minimal risk research
IRB may grant exception from informed consent for emergency research under § 50.24
Phase 1 studies of radioactive drugs must include data for dosimetry calculations
Radioactive drug applications must include radiation-absorbed dose calculations for whole body and critical organs
Applications must include plans for assessing pediatric safety and effectiveness
Sponsors must provide any additional information requested by FDA for application review
References to previously submitted information must identify file name, reference number, volume and page number
References to third-party submissions must include signed authorization from the original submitter
Submit accurate and complete English translation of all non-English IND parts
Submit original literature publications for any translated documents
Submit one original and two copies of all IND submissions, amendments and reports
Amend IND as needed to ensure clinical investigations follow included protocols
Submit separate IND for clinical investigations with emergency research informed consent exceptions
IRB must document written procedures as required by § 56.108
IRB must maintain statements of significant new findings provided to subjects
Initial IND submissions must be numbered 000
Subsequent IND submissions must be numbered chronologically with three-digit serial numbers
Sponsors must identify on cover sheet if investigation has informed consent exception under §50.24
Sponsors must submit protocol amendments to FDA for any new study not in existing IND
New study protocols must be approved by the IRB before study begins
Submit protocol amendments for safety-significant changes to Phase 1 protocols
Submit protocol amendment for any increase in drug dosage or duration of exposure beyond current protocol
Submit protocol amendment for any significant increase in number of study subjects
Submit protocol amendment for significant changes in study design like adding/dropping control groups
Submit protocol amendment when adding new safety monitoring procedures or dropping existing ones
Submit protocol changes to FDA for review before implementation
Obtain IRB approval for protocol changes before implementation
Protocol amendments for immediate hazards must be subsequently notified to FDA
Protocol amendments for immediate hazards must be notified to reviewing IRB per §56.104(c)
Sponsor must submit protocol amendment when adding new investigator to existing protocol
Sponsor must notify FDA within 30 days of adding new investigator
Protocol amendments must be clearly identified with specific amendment type in title
New protocol amendments must include copy of protocol and description of key differences
Submit protocol amendments before implementing any new protocol or protocol changes
Reference specific technical information in IND to support clinically significant protocol changes
Identify location of referenced IND information by name, reference number, volume and page number
Submit new investigator additions and investigator information updates at 30-day intervals
Group multiple protocol/change submissions into a single submission when feasible
FDA may send disqualification notice to sponsors and investigators
FDA may publish disqualification notice in Federal Register
Sponsor shall report essential IND information via information amendment when not covered by other reports
Information amendments must prominently identify their contents with clear headers
Information amendments must include a statement of nature and purpose
Information amendments must contain organized data in scientific review format
Information amendments should not be submitted more frequently than every 30 days
Submit all technical information supporting IND if not referencing scientific literature
Document any anticipated severe or serious risks based on toxicology
Phase 1 study protocols may be less detailed and more flexible than Phase 2/3 protocols
All protocols must include investigator qualifications and contact information
Provide copies of all labels and labeling to be given to investigators
Submit environmental analysis requirements or claim categorical exclusion
Submit protocol amendments for significant changes to Phase 2 or 3 protocols
Protocol change amendments must describe changes and reference original submission
Sponsors must report discontinuation of clinical investigations via information amendment
Life-threatening adverse events must be reported if they place patient at immediate risk of death
Death must be reported as a serious adverse event outcome
Inpatient hospitalization or prolonged hospitalization must be reported as serious adverse events
Significant incapacity or disruption of normal life functions must be reported as serious adverse events
Congenital anomalies and birth defects must be reported as serious adverse events
Important medical events requiring intervention may be considered serious adverse events based on medical judgment
Report any adverse event with reasonable possibility of being caused by the drug as a suspected adverse reaction
List all known adverse events in the investigator brochure at their observed specificity and severity
Document risk information in general investigational plan if no investigator brochure exists
Report adverse events of greater severity than those listed in documentation as unexpected
Classify adverse events with causal evidence as suspected adverse reactions
Sponsors must promptly review all safety information from foreign and domestic sources
Sponsors must review safety data from clinical and epidemiological investigations
Sponsors must review safety data from animal and in vitro studies
Sponsors must review scientific literature and unpublished papers for safety information
Sponsors must notify FDA and investigators of potential serious risks within 15 calendar days
Sponsors must review foreign regulatory authority reports for drugs not marketed in US
Sponsors must identify all previous IND safety reports submitted to FDA about similar suspected adverse reactions
Sponsors must analyze significance of suspected adverse reactions compared to previous reports
Sponsors must report any suspected adverse reaction that is both serious and unexpected
Report adverse events as suspected reactions only if evidence suggests causal relationship with the drug
Report single occurrences of uncommon events known to be strongly associated with drug exposure
Report events not commonly associated with drug exposure but uncommon in the exposed population
Sponsor must report findings from epidemiological studies that suggest significant human risk
Sponsor must report findings from pooled analysis studies that suggest significant human risk
Significant safety findings must trigger updates to protocol and informed consent documents
Sponsor must report animal testing findings suggesting significant human risk
Sponsor must report in vitro testing findings suggesting significant human risk
Report findings of mutagenicity, teratogenicity, carcinogenicity near human exposure levels
Sponsor must report any clinically important increase in serious suspected adverse reaction rates
Submit IND safety reports in narrative format, FDA Form 3500A, or processable electronic format
Foreign suspected adverse reactions may be submitted on CIOMS I Form instead of FDA Form 3500A
Submit pooled analyses and overall findings from studies in narrative format
Each FDA notification must be clearly marked as 'IND Safety Report'
Submit additional requested FDA data within 15 calendar days of request
Report unexpected fatal or life-threatening adverse reactions to FDA within 7 calendar days of receipt
Submit IND safety reports in FDA-specified format when required
Submit IND safety reports at FDA-specified frequency when required
Submit annual IND progress report within 60 days of IND anniversary date
Submit IND safety reports for adverse reactions in clinical studies of marketed US drugs
Obtain FDA division director approval before changing safety report format or frequency
Study endpoints must be reported to FDA by sponsor as described in protocol
Serious unexpected adverse events with suspected drug causation must be reported even if part of study endpoint
Sponsor must promptly investigate all safety information received
Followup information to IND safety report must be submitted when available and marked as 'Followup'
Initially unreported adverse events later found reportable must be submitted within 15 calendar days of determination
Provide a brief summary of the status of each study in progress and completed during previous year
Include study title, protocol number, purpose, patient population, and completion status in summary
Report total planned subjects, current enrollment by age/gender/race, completions, and dropouts
Provide brief description of study results or interim results if available
Sponsors may deny that submitted reports constitute admission of drug causing adverse events
Submit narrative or tabular summary of most frequent adverse experiences by body system
Submit summary of all IND safety reports from the past year
Provide list of subjects who died during the investigation with cause of death
List subjects who dropped out due to adverse experiences
Submit description of findings related to drug actions, dose response and bioavailability
List completed and in-progress preclinical studies with major findings
Summarize significant manufacturing or microbiological changes from past year
General investigational plan must contain information required under § 312.23(a)(3)(iv)
Provide description of investigator brochure revisions and copy of new brochure when revised
Report significant Phase 1 protocol modifications made during previous year
Summarize significant foreign marketing developments with drug during past year
Notify FDA when withdrawing an IND
End all clinical investigations when IND is withdrawn
Notify all investigators and IRBs if IND withdrawn for safety reasons
Sponsor must submit an IND application to FDA before clinical investigation
Sponsor must comply with all requirements in parts 50 and 56 for clinical investigations
Investigators must conduct research in compliance with parts 50 and 56
IND goes into effect 30 days after FDA receipt unless clinical hold is imposed
FDA must notify sponsor in writing of IND receipt date
Sponsor may ship drug to named investigators 30 days after FDA receives IND
Investigators must not administer drug until IND is in effect
FDA may communicate with sponsors about IND deficiencies or need for more data
FDA will provide advice on specific IND matters upon sponsor's request
FDA communications without clinical hold orders are advisory only and require no modifications
When a study is on clinical hold, no new subjects may receive the investigational drug
Existing patients in a study placed on clinical hold must stop receiving investigational drug
FDA may place clinical hold on Phase 1 studies if subjects face unreasonable risk of illness/injury
Clinical investigators named in IND must be qualified through scientific training and experience
Investigator brochure must be accurate and complete without misleading information
IND must contain sufficient information to assess subject risks per § 312.23
Studies for life-threatening conditions must not exclude participants based on reproductive risks alone
Women with reproductive potential must not include pregnant women in definition
Life-threatening illnesses must be defined as conditions where death likelihood is high without intervention
Gender-specific studies may be conducted under special circumstances
Single-gender studies must have concurrent or planned studies including the other gender
FDA may place Phase 2 or 3 studies on clinical hold if conditions in b(1)(i) through b(1)(v) apply
FDA may place studies on hold if protocol is clearly deficient in meeting stated objectives
FDA may place expanded access IND on hold if expanded access criteria in subpart I are not satisfied
Expanded access protocols must comply with submission requirements in subpart I
FDA may place ongoing expanded access IND on hold if criteria are no longer satisfied
Non-adequate/well-controlled studies may be put on hold if interfering with adequate/well-controlled studies
Non-adequate/well-controlled studies may be put on hold if impeding enrollment in other studies
Sufficient quantities of investigational drug must exist for both non-controlled and controlled investigations
FDA may halt studies if drug shows lack of effectiveness in well-controlled investigations
FDA may halt studies if another drug shows better benefit/risk for same indication and population
Sponsors must actively pursue marketing approval with due diligence
Clinical holds for certain criteria should only apply to new enrollment, not existing participants
FDA may place holds on investigations involving informed consent exceptions under §50.24
FDA may place clinical holds if conditions in paragraphs (b)(1) or (b)(2) apply
Criteria in § 50.24 must be satisfied and submitted for informed consent exceptions
Presidential waiver is required for investigations with informed consent exceptions under § 50.23(d)
FDA must discuss deficiencies that may lead to clinical holds
FDA must protect patients from immediate risks during clinical investigations
FDA must attempt to resolve issues with sponsor before issuing clinical hold order
Clinical hold orders must identify affected studies and explain the basis for action
Division Director must provide written explanation within 30 days of clinical hold
Investigations can only resume after FDA notification
Sponsor must correct deficiencies before clinical hold can be removed
Clinical hold orders may be issued by telephone or other rapid communication
FDA shall respond to clinical hold responses within 30 calendar days of receipt
Sponsors cannot proceed with clinical trials under hold until FDA notifies the hold is lifted
Sponsors may request reconsideration of clinical hold decisions under § 312.48
FDA may place IND on inactive status if clinical hold exceeds 1 year
Sponsors must end all clinical investigations if IND is terminated
Sponsors must recall or dispose of unused drug supplies upon IND termination
FDA may terminate IND if human subjects would be exposed to unreasonable risk of illness or injury
IND must contain sufficient information to assess safety of clinical investigations
Manufacturing facilities and controls must maintain appropriate drug quality standards for subject safety
Clinical investigations must be conducted as described in IND protocols
Drug must not be promoted or distributed for unauthorized commercial purposes
IND submissions must not contain untrue statements or omit required material information
Sponsors must submit accurate annual reports of investigations per § 312.33
Sponsors must report serious and unexpected adverse experiences per § 312.32
Sponsors must suspend investigations placed on clinical hold under § 312.42(b)(4)
FDA may terminate INDs that remain inactive for 5 or more years
Phase 2/3 investigational plans must be reasonable scientific plans to determine drug safety and efficacy
Sponsors have 30 days to respond to FDA IND termination proposals with corrections or explanations
Sponsor may provide written explanation/correction or request conference with FDA upon notification
IND shall be terminated if sponsor does not respond within allocated time
FDA must inform sponsor in writing if explanation/correction is not accepted
Sponsor must request regulatory hearing within 10 days of receiving FDA's nonacceptance
FDA shall immediately terminate IND if investigation presents immediate danger to health
FDA may terminate an IND if it poses an unreasonable risk to subjects
FDA shall notify sponsor in writing before placing IND on inactive status
Sponsors have 30 days to respond to proposed inactive status notification
All investigators must be notified if IND is placed on inactive status
Drug stocks must be returned or disposed of when IND becomes inactive
Annual reports are not required for INDs on inactive status
FDA may place IND on inactive status after 2 years with no subject enrollment
Submit protocol amendment with investigational plan when resuming inactive IND
Wait 30 days after FDA receives protocol amendment before resuming inactive IND investigations
Submit additional information supporting investigation via information amendment if needed
FDA may terminate IND that remains inactive for 5 or more years
Hold meetings between sponsor and FDA to resolve questions during clinical investigation
Scientific/medical meetings shall be conducted and documented according to part 10
Free, full and open communication should occur about scientific/medical questions during clinical investigation
End-of-Phase 2 meetings should be held to determine safety of proceeding to Phase 3
End-of-Phase 2 meetings should evaluate Phase 3 plans and protocols
End-of-Phase 2 meetings should assess plans for pediatric safety and effectiveness
Pre-NDA meetings should be held before marketing application submission
Any IND sponsor may request and obtain an end-of-Phase 2 meeting
End-of-Phase 2 meetings should occur before major Phase 3 commitments are made
Sponsor should submit Phase 3 plan information at least 1 month before end-of-Phase 2 meeting
Submission must include summaries of Phase 1 and 2 investigations
Submission must include specific protocols for Phase 3 clinical studies
Submission must include plans for pediatric studies with timeline
FDA must schedule meetings at times convenient for both FDA and sponsor
Both sponsors and FDA may bring consultants to meetings
Meetings should focus on establishing agreement on overall Phase 3 plan and study design
FDA must provide judgment on required pediatric studies and deferral status
FDA must record meeting agreements in minutes per §10.65 and provide to sponsor
Studies conducted per agreement shall be presumed sufficient for marketing approval
Sponsor should initiate pre-NDA/BLA meeting arrangements with FDA reviewing division
Sponsor should submit meeting materials to FDA at least 1 month before pre-NDA/BLA meeting
Pre-NDA/BLA meetings must identify studies relied on to establish drug effectiveness
Pre-NDA/BLA meetings must identify status of pediatric safety and effectiveness studies
Application must include summary of clinical studies to be submitted
Application must propose format for organizing data submission
Application must include status of pediatric studies
Sponsor should first attempt to resolve disputes with FDA division responsible for IND review
Unresolved disputes may be raised with designated FDA ombudsman
Ombudsman shall investigate disputes and facilitate timely resolution
Sponsors must select qualified investigators
Sponsors must provide investigators with information needed to conduct investigations properly
Sponsors must ensure proper monitoring of investigations
Sponsors must ensure investigations follow the IND general plan and protocols
Sponsors must maintain an effective IND for the investigations
Sponsors must promptly inform FDA and investigators of significant new adverse effects or risks
Sponsors should discuss scientific/medical disputes directly with reviewing officials
FDA must attempt to grant meeting requests involving important issues at mutually convenient times
End-of-Phase 2 and pre-NDA meetings shall provide forum for resolving scientific/medical issues
FDA may invite advisory committee members or consultants to dispute resolution meetings
Sponsors may bring their own consultants to meetings with FDA
Transfer of sponsor obligations to CRO must be described in writing
Written transfer must specify which obligations are being assumed by the CRO
Contract research organizations must comply with all sponsor regulations they assume responsibility for
Sponsors must select investigators qualified by training and experience to investigate the drug
Sponsors shall only ship investigational drugs to participating investigators
Sponsors must obtain signed FDA-1572 forms from investigators before they begin participation
FDA-1572 forms must include investigator name and address
FDA-1572 forms must include protocol names and code numbers for studies to be conducted
Provide name and address of medical schools, hospitals, or research facilities conducting clinical investigations
Provide name and address of clinical laboratory facilities used in the study
Provide name and address of IRB responsible for study review and approval
Investigator must conduct studies according to current protocols and notify sponsor of any changes
Investigator must personally conduct or supervise the investigations
Inform subjects that drugs are investigational and obtain proper informed consent
Report adverse experiences to sponsor per § 312.64
Ensure all staff assisting in study conduct understand investigator brochure including risks
An IRB compliant with part 56 must review and approve the clinical investigation
Investigators must promptly report all unanticipated problems involving risks to human subjects to the IRB
Investigators must obtain IRB approval before making changes to the research
Changes may be made without IRB approval only to eliminate immediate hazards to subjects
Investigators must provide a list of all subinvestigators who will assist in the investigation
Investigators must provide curriculum vitae or statement of qualifications
Investigator must provide documentation of education, training and experience qualifying them as drug trial expert
Phase 1 investigations must include planned duration and maximum number of subjects
Phase 2/3 protocols must specify subject numbers, characteristics, clinical observations and laboratory tests
Investigators must provide financial disclosure information for certification statements
Investigators must update financial information for 1 year after study completion
Sponsor shall select monitors qualified by training and experience
Sponsor shall monitor progress of all investigations involving exception from informed consent
Sponsor must submit copies of public disclosures to IND file and FDA Docket when received from IRB
Sponsor shall monitor for IRB determinations of non-approval based on informed consent exceptions
Sponsor must notify FDA in writing when IRB cannot approve research due to ethical concerns
Sponsor must notify other investigators and IRBs about research that cannot be approved
Sponsor must provide investigator brochure to each participating clinical investigator before study start
Sponsor shall monitor the progress of all clinical investigations under their IND
Sponsor must inform investigators of new drug observations, particularly adverse effects and safe use
Important safety information must be relayed to investigators per § 312.32
Sponsor shall secure compliance or discontinue drug shipments if investigator violates requirements
When ending investigator participation, sponsor shall require return or disposal of investigational drug
Safety information may be distributed via investigator brochures, reprints, reports, letters or other means
Sponsor shall review and evaluate drug safety and effectiveness evidence from investigators
Sponsor must submit safety reports to FDA as required under § 312.32
Sponsor shall submit annual investigation progress reports per § 312.33
Sponsor must discontinue investigations within 5 days if drug presents unreasonable risk
Sponsor shall notify FDA, IRBs and investigators of investigation discontinuance
Sponsor shall maintain records of investigational drug receipt, shipment and disposition
Sponsor must maintain records of drug shipments including recipient, date, quantity and batch marks
Sponsor must maintain complete records of financial interests paid to clinical investigators
Records must be retained for 2 years after marketing application approval
If application not approved, records must be kept 2 years after discontinuing investigational use
Sponsor must ensure return of unused investigational drug from investigators who discontinue participation
Sponsor must maintain written records of investigational drug disposition
Investigator must conduct investigation according to signed statement, plan and regulations
Investigator must protect rights, safety and welfare of subjects under their care
Investigator must control investigational drugs
Investigator must obtain informed consent from each subject receiving the drug
Sponsor must retain reserve samples of test articles used in bioequivalence/bioavailability studies
Sponsor must release reserve samples to FDA upon request
Sponsor must allow FDA officers to access and verify clinical investigation records and reports
Sponsor must submit records/reports to FDA upon written request
Sponsor must stop drug shipments to investigators who fail to maintain/provide required records
Controlled substance records must be made available to DEA for inspection upon request
Controlled substances must be stored in securely locked, substantially constructed cabinet/enclosure
Access to controlled substance storage must be limited to prevent theft/diversion
Investigator shall administer drug only to subjects under their personal supervision or subinvestigator supervision
Investigator shall not supply investigational drug to unauthorized persons
Investigator must maintain records of drug disposition including dates, quantity and subject use
Investigator must return unused drug supplies to sponsor when study ends
Investigator must maintain accurate case histories for each subject receiving investigational drug
Case histories must include signed and dated consent forms
Case history must document that informed consent was obtained prior to study participation
Investigators shall retain records for 2 years after marketing application approval
Investigators shall furnish all reports to the drug sponsor
Investigators must immediately report any serious adverse events to the sponsor
Adverse event reports must include assessment of possible drug causation
Serious adverse events that are study endpoints must be reported per protocol
Investigator must immediately report death from anaphylaxis events to the sponsor
Investigator must record and report nonserious adverse events according to protocol timeline
Investigator shall provide final report to sponsor after completing investigation participation
Investigator shall provide accurate financial information to sponsor for certification/disclosure
Investigator shall update financial information for changes during study and 1 year after completion
Investigator shall ensure IRB review and approval of proposed clinical study
Investigators must report all unanticipated problems involving risk to human subjects to the IRB promptly
Investigators must obtain IRB approval before making changes to research protocols
Investigators shall provide FDA officials access to inspect and copy research records upon request
Subject names must remain confidential unless detailed case review is required
Controlled substances must be stored in a securely locked, substantially constructed cabinet
Access to controlled substance storage must be limited to prevent theft or diversion
FDA must provide written notice to investigators who repeatedly or deliberately fail to comply with regulations
FDA must offer non-compliant investigators opportunity to explain in writing or informal conference
Centers must discontinue disqualification if investigator explanation is accepted
FDA must provide regulatory hearing opportunity if explanation not accepted
Commissioner must evaluate all information before determining investigator disqualification
Investigators must not submit false information in required reports
Commissioner must notify investigator when they are ineligible to receive test articles
Commissioner must notify sponsors when their investigator is ineligible
Commissioner must notify IRBs when an investigator is ineligible
Procedures must expedite development of therapies for life-threatening illnesses
Procedures must expedite development of therapies for severely-debilitating illnesses
FDA may apply flexibility in safety and effectiveness standards based on drug types and uses
FDA must notify investigators of ineligibility determination and explain the basis
Ineligible investigators cannot conduct clinical investigations supporting FDA applications
FDA must examine applications containing data from ineligible investigators for unreliable data
FDA must notify sponsor if remaining data is inadequate after removing unreliable data
Sponsors shall have opportunity for regulatory hearing under part 16
Commissioner shall terminate IND immediately upon finding unreliable data
Commissioner must notify sponsor and IRBs of IND termination
Sponsor shall have opportunity for regulatory hearing before FDA on IND reinstatement
Sponsor must submit investigation results to FDA even if data deemed unreliable
Commissioner shall withdraw product approval if it cannot be justified after removing unreliable data
Ineligible investigator may be reinstated upon providing adequate compliance assurances
FDA shall apply flexible standards while maintaining safety and effectiveness guarantees
Drug benefits must be evaluated relative to disease severity
These procedures apply to drugs studied for life-threatening or severely-debilitating diseases
Sponsors may request early meetings with FDA to review preclinical and clinical study design
FDA may invite outside experts to early consultation meetings when appropriate
FDA reviewing officials shall honor requests for meetings with scientific consultants when resources permit
Sponsors may consult FDA on applicability of procedures to specific products
Sponsors may request pre-IND meetings with FDA before initial IND submission
Pre-IND meetings shall review and agree on animal studies design needed for human testing
Sponsors may request end-of-phase-1 meetings when phase 1 clinical data is available
Reach agreement on design of phase 2 controlled clinical trials for safety and effectiveness data
Discuss design and timing of pediatric patient studies
FDA may request submission of treatment protocol after promising phase 2 results
Treatment protocols must be reviewed under procedures in §§ 312.305 and 312.320
Treatment protocol remains active while marketing application data is assembled and reviewed
Clinical hold may be placed on ongoing protocols per § 312.42(b)(3)(ii)
FDA shall document agreements reached during end-of-phase 1 meetings using procedures from § 312.47(b)(1)
FDA shall evaluate medical risk-benefit judgment for final marketing approval decisions
FDA shall consider if drug benefits outweigh known and potential risks
FDA shall consider disease severity and alternative therapy availability in approval decisions
FDA shall seek advice from outside expert consultants or advisory committees for end-of-phase 1 marketing approvals
FDA must notify relevant advisory committee members when marketing applications are filed and available for review
FDA must describe in the response letter why research design results were insufficient for marketing approval
FDA must include advisory committee recommendations in the response letter
Marketing applications must comply with requirements in part 314 or part 600
FDA may request sponsor agreement for postmarketing Phase 4 studies upon approval
Phase 4 studies may include different doses, schedules, populations or longer duration than Phase 2
FDA may conduct focused regulatory research on critical rate-limiting aspects
FDA must monitor progress of clinical trials and facilitate their appropriate progress
Informed consent must be obtained from trial participants per Part 50
Institutional review board approval is required per Part 56
Animal studies must be reviewed before initial human testing
IND safety reports must be submitted to monitor adverse drug experiences
Safety update reports must be submitted during marketing application review
Post-marketing adverse reaction reports must be submitted
Imported investigational drugs must be subject to an active IND under § 312.40
US consignee for imported drugs must be the IND sponsor
US consignee may be a qualified investigator named in the IND
Foreign sponsor's domestic agent must be identified in IND with defined responsibilities
Exported investigational drugs must comply with receiving country's laws
Recipients of exported drugs must be investigators in an approved IND study
Drug exports to EU/EEA and specified countries must comply with the importing country's laws
Exported drugs not under IND are exempt from label requirements in § 312.6(a)
Exporters must send certification email to OGPSExecSec@fda.hhs.gov when drug is first exported
Export certification must include drug trade name, generic name, and dosage form
Exporters must maintain records documenting compliance with certification requirements
Exported drug must meet foreign purchaser's or consignee's specifications
Outer shipping package must be labeled to indicate package is for export from US
Drug must not be sold or offered for sale in the United States
Clinical investigation must be conducted in accordance with § 312.120
Drug must be manufactured and handled in conformity with current good manufacturing practices
Drug must not present imminent hazard to public health in US or foreign country
Drug must be labeled in accordance with foreign country's laws
Provide written statement explaining why compliance with specified paragraphs is not feasible
Obtain written statement from importing country's government official agreeing with exporter's statement
Official statement must confirm drug is for national emergency stockpile use only
Official statement must describe the potential national emergency warranting the export
Obtain written statement showing Secretary of HHS agrees with importing country's findings
Direct requests for Secretary's statement to Secretary's Operations Center
Export requests may be sent to HHS by fax at 202-619-7870
Export requests may be sent to HHS by email at HHS.SOC@hhs.gov
FDA authorization must be obtained before exporting investigational new drugs
For emergency exports, provide written statement explaining why compliance with requirements is not feasible
For emergency exports, provide documentation from importing country's government official
Requests for emergency drug export determinations must be sent to the Secretary's Operations Center
Export requests may be submitted by FAX to 202-619-7870
Export requests may be submitted by email to HHS.SOC@hhs.gov
Drug exports must not occur if the IND for the clinical investigation is no longer in effect
Drug exports must not occur if requirements in section 802(b)(1), (f), or (g) are no longer met
FDA must accept well-designed foreign clinical studies not conducted under IND as support for marketing approval
Foreign clinical studies must be conducted in accordance with Good Clinical Practice (GCP)
GCP must ensure data and results are credible and accurate
GCP must protect rights, safety and well-being of trial subjects
New insulin and antibiotic products may be exported for investigational use under section 801(e)(1)
Investigational drugs must comply with importing country laws
Obtain independent ethics committee approval before initiating a study
Ethics committee must conduct continuing review of ongoing studies
Obtain documented informed consent from subject or legal representative before study initiation
FDA may validate study data through onsite inspection if deemed necessary
Studies not meeting conditions in paragraph (a)(1) cannot be used to support IND or marketing approval
Marketing approval based solely on foreign clinical data must comply with § 314.106
Submit description of actions taken to ensure research conformed to GCP
Submit investigator qualifications documentation
Submit description of research facilities
Submit detailed protocol summary and study results
Submit description of drug substance and product used including components and specifications
Submit proof study is adequate and well controlled if supporting drug effectiveness
Submit name and address of IEC that reviewed the study
Sponsor must maintain records of IEC members' names and qualifications
Sponsor must make IEC member records available for agency review upon request
Study must include summary of IEC's decision to approve or modify and approve the study
Study must document how informed consent was obtained from participants
Study must describe any incentives provided to study participants
Sponsor must document how study monitoring ensured protocol compliance
Sponsor must maintain signed investigator commitments to GCP compliance
Sponsor must make investigator GCP commitments available for agency review upon request
Sponsors may request waivers from FDA for applicable requirements in paragraphs (a)(1) and (b)
Waiver requests must include explanation of why compliance is unnecessary or unachievable
Waiver requests must describe alternative actions that satisfy the requirement's purpose
FDA may grant waivers if determined to be in the interest of public health
Records for foreign clinical studies supporting marketing approval must be retained for 2 years after agency decision
Records for foreign clinical studies supporting only INDs must be retained for 2 years after IND submission
FDA shall not disclose existence of investigational new drug applications unless previously publicly disclosed
Data disclosure for new drug INDs must follow confidentiality provisions in § 314.430
Data disclosure for biological product INDs must follow provisions in §§ 601.50 and 601.51
FDA shall provide IND safety reports to individuals who received the investigational drug upon request
Requests for public IND info under informed consent exceptions must be submitted via Freedom of Information Act
Send initial IND submissions for CDER-regulated drug products to the Central Document Room in Beltsville, MD
Send initial IND submissions for CDER-regulated biological products to the Central Document Room in Beltsville, MD
Send initial IND submissions for CBER-regulated biological products to the Document Control Center in FDA
Submit initial IND to either CDER or CBER based on which Center regulates the product
The responsible Center must inform sponsors which CDER/CBER division is responsible for their IND
IND amendments and reports must be sent to the appropriate center and marked for the responsible division
The outside wrapper of each submission shall state the content type (e.g. 'IND Application', 'Protocol Amendment')
Export-related IND correspondence shall be submitted to the International Affairs Staff at the specified address
FDA provides guidance documents to help comply with requirements
CDER and CBER must maintain lists of applicable guidance documents on the Internet
Guidance document lists must be published annually in the Federal Register
Label investigational drugs for laboratory research with 'Not for use in humans' warning
Label biological products for in vitro diagnostic tests with appropriate caution statement
Verify consignee regularly conducts laboratory research tests before shipping
Ensure shipped investigational drugs will only be used for in vitro or animal laboratory research
Request CBER list copies from FDA Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research office
Maintain records showing name and address of experts receiving drug shipments
Keep records of shipment date, quantity and batch/code mark for each delivery
Maintain paragraph (a)(1)(i) shipment records for 2 years
Allow FDA officers to access and verify shipment records upon request
FDA may terminate shipping authorization if sponsor fails to comply with conditions
FDA must notify shipper of compliance findings and allow correction opportunity
Drug shipper shall ensure return of all unused drug supplies from investigators when investigation ends or terminates
Alternative disposition of unused drugs requires written authorization from the shipper
Alternative drug disposition must not expose humans to risks directly or indirectly
Shipper shall maintain records of any alternative drug disposition
Expanded access requirements apply to investigational new drugs and approved drugs with limited REMS availability
FDA must determine if patients have a serious or immediately life-threatening disease or condition
FDA must verify no comparable or satisfactory alternative therapy exists for the disease/condition
Immediately life-threatening conditions must have likelihood of death within months or premature death without treatment
Serious diseases/conditions must substantially impact day-to-day functioning with persistent/recurrent morbidity
Clinical judgment must determine disease seriousness based on survival, functioning and progression factors
Patient benefit must justify potential risks of treatment use
Expanded access must not interfere with clinical investigations for marketing approval
Submit expanded access request as new IND or protocol amendment to existing IND
Include FDA Form 1571 cover sheet with expanded access submission
Provide rationale for drug use including list of available therapeutic options
Explain why investigational drug is preferable to available therapeutic options
Patient selection criteria must be documented for expanded access submissions
Drug administration method, dose and therapy duration must be specified
Manufacturing facility details must be described in submission
Chemistry and controls information must ensure proper drug identification and quality
Submissions must be clearly marked 'EXPANDED ACCESS SUBMISSION' on mailing cover
Treatment IND/protocol box on Form FDA 1571 must be checked if applicable
Clinical procedures and monitoring methods must be described to evaluate drug effects
Licensed physicians administering investigational drugs under expanded access are considered investigators
Entities submitting expanded access INDs must comply with sponsor responsibilities in subpart D
Physicians submitting expanded access INDs must comply with sponsor-investigator responsibilities
Investigators must report adverse drug events to the sponsor
Investigators must ensure informed consent requirements are met per part 50
Investigators must obtain IRB review for expanded access use per part 56
Investigators must maintain accurate case histories
Licensed physicians must be qualified to administer investigational drugs for expanded access use
Sponsors must submit IND safety reports to FDA
Sponsors must submit annual reports when IND/protocol continues for 1+ year
Sponsors must provide physicians with investigator brochure if one exists
Sponsors must maintain drug disposition records
FDA may permit investigational drug use for individual patient treatment by licensed physician
Expanded access IND becomes effective 30 days after FDA receipt or earlier FDA notification
Emergency expanded access use may only begin when authorized by FDA reviewing official
FDA may place any expanded access IND or protocol on clinical hold
Physician must determine probable drug risk is not greater than disease risk
FDA must determine patient cannot obtain drug under another IND/protocol
Expanded access submission must demonstrate criteria compliance with supporting information
Sponsors may amend existing IND to include protocol for individual patient expanded access
FDA may permit investigational drug use for smaller patient populations than typical treatment IND
Licensed physicians must obtain sponsor permission for FDA to reference IND information
Treatment is limited to single course unless FDA authorizes multiple/chronic therapy
Licensed physician or sponsor must provide FDA written report at treatment conclusion
Sponsors must provide a summary of expanded access use results including adverse effects
FDA may require sponsors to monitor individual patient expanded access for extended duration use
Emergency expanded access requests can be made by phone, fax or electronic communications
Biologics emergency requests must be directed to CBER Office of Communication at specified contacts
Non-biologics emergency requests must be directed to CDER Division of Drug Information
After-hours emergency requests must be directed to FDA Emergency Call Center
Licensed physician or sponsor must explain how expanded access use meets requirements of §§ 312.305 and 312.310
Submit expanded access submission within 15 working days of FDA authorization
Expanded access may be granted for drugs not being developed due to rare disease recruitment challenges
Expanded access may be granted when patients cannot participate in existing clinical trials
Expanded access may be granted for approved drugs no longer marketed for safety reasons
Expanded access may be granted for drugs with same active moiety as unavailable approved products
The criteria in § 312.305(a) must be met for expanded access
Evidence must show drug safety at proposed dose/duration to justify clinical trial
Preliminary clinical evidence of drug effectiveness must be available
Expanded access submission must meet requirements of § 312.305(b)
Submission must state if drug is being developed and describe patient population
Sponsor must explain why undeveloped drug cannot be developed for expanded access
Sponsor must explain why clinical trial patients need expanded access treatment
FDA must determine if expanded access should continue based on annual report review
FDA may permit investigational drugs for widespread treatment use
Sponsors must monitor expanded access protocols to ensure physician compliance
FDA may request sponsor submit IND/protocol as patient enrollment increases
FDA must evaluate if expanded access interferes with clinical development
Criteria in section 312.305(a) must be met for treatment IND approval
Drug must be investigated in controlled clinical trial under IND for expanded access use
Sponsor must actively pursue marketing approval for expanded access use with due diligence
For serious diseases, sufficient clinical evidence must include data from phase 3 or compelling phase 2 trials
For life-threatening diseases, evidence must show drug may be effective without unreasonable risk
Expanded access submission must include information proving criteria in 312.305(a) are met
Expanded access submission must meet requirements of 312.305(b)
Sponsors must monitor treatment protocols to ensure physician compliance
Sponsors must ensure licensed physicians follow the treatment protocol
Sponsors must verify physicians comply with investigator regulations
Only licensed physicians may conduct treatment under the protocol
